channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: A letter to readers
item.description: L.A. Times owners Patrick Soon-Shiong and Michele Chan Soon-Shiong write to our readers about the racial injustice in America.
item.content:encoded: L.A. Times owners Patrick Soon-Shiong and Michele Chan Soon-Shiong write to our readers about the racial injustice in America.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 05: I sign with the words "Black Lives Matter," is taped to a pole across the street from City Hall, where nearly 1,000 people gathered to protest the death of George Floyd and in support of Black Lives Matter, in downtown, Los Angeles, CA, on Friday, June 5, 2020. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Community organizer who trains police on bias injured by rubber bullet during protest
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Derrick Sanderlin volunteers training San Jose Police recruits on bias and community-building. He's now wondering whether those lessons fell on deaf ears.
item.content:encoded: Derrick Sanderlin volunteers training San Jose Police recruits on bias and community-building. He's now wondering whether those lessons fell on deaf ears.

media:content.media:description: Derrick Sanderlin, 27, and his wife Cayla, 29.

item.title: 'I could have died too.' Voices from the streets of L.A. as protests spread across the city
item.dc:creator: Sonali Kohli, Sarah Parvini, Ruben Vives, Amy Kaufman, Arit John, Colleen Shalby, Kevin Baxter
item.description: As protests against police brutality and the killing of George Floyd spread across Southern California this weekend, here are a sample of the voices on the streets.
item.content:encoded: As protests against police brutality and the killing of George Floyd spread across Southern California this weekend, here are a sample of the voices on the streets.

media:content.media:description: BURBANK, CA - JUNE 04: Stevie Nelson, left, at a protest over police brutality and the death of George Floyd held in front of North Hollywood Police Station. Rally was organized by Showing up for Racial Justice (SURJ), an organization dedicated to organizing white folks across the nation to show up and fight the root causes of racism. North Hollywood Police Station on Thursday, June 4, 2020 in Burbank, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Thousands turn out for peaceful demonstrations on Saturday around Los Angeles
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Colleen Shalby, Arit John, Amy Kaufman, Sarah Parvini, Kevin Baxter, Ruben Vives, Sonali Kohli
item.description: Thousands of people gather at more than a dozen protests around Los Angeles over the death of George Floyd and others at the hands of police.
item.content:encoded: Thousands of people gather at more than a dozen protests around Los Angeles over the death of George Floyd and others at the hands of police.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CALIFORNIA JUNE 6, 2020-A family member of Breonna Taylor, right, is hugged by another woman after speaking to protestors in beverly Hills Saturday. The protest was organzied by the Refuse Fascism group. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'I guess America is finally listening.' Why George Floyd protests have spread to affluent white suburbs
item.dc:creator: Liam Dillon, Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: Protests over the police killing of George Floyd are springing up in more affluent, white and suburban areas than law enforcement protests have before. Experts say the trend reflects a sea change in the views of white residents.
item.content:encoded: Protests over the police killing of George Floyd are springing up in more affluent, white and suburban areas than law enforcement protests have before. Experts say the trend reflects a sea change in the views of white residents.

media:content.media:description: NEWPORT BEACH, CA - JUNE 03: Hundreds of Black Lives Matter supporters march down the bike path past beach-front homes to protest against racism and Minneapolis police officers' involvement in the May 25 death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man Wednesday, June 3, 2020 in Newport Beach, CA. It was the second of four protests Wednesday in Newport Beach. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Earthquake: Magnitude 3.3 quake felt near Gilroy, Calif.
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude 3.3 earthquake was reported Friday afternoon at 4:09 p.m. three miles from Gilroy, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.3 earthquake was reported Friday afternoon at 4:09 p.m. three miles from Gilroy, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

media:content.media:description: A 3.3-magnitude earthquake was felt near Watsonville, Calif.

item.title: ICE alleges coercion behind California hunger strike; detainee calls agency officials 'liars'
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: Over the years, hunger strikes have been a tool used to bring attention to what's happening inside immigrant detention facilities.
item.content:encoded: Over the years, hunger strikes have been a tool used to bring attention to what's happening inside immigrant detention facilities.

media:content.media:description: Hunger strikers at Mesa Verde ICE Processing Center in Bakersfield captured by drone during a sit-in protest on April 10.

item.title: After George Floyd's death, a time to listen and learn
item.dc:creator: Nita Lelyveld
item.description: Protests over the killing of George Floyd call on some of us to listen and learn
item.content:encoded: Protests over the killing of George Floyd call on some of us to listen and learn

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 05: Artists have memorialized George Floyd, who died while in-custody of the Minneapolis Police, with murals and street art along Wilmington Ave. and 105th St. in Watts on Friday, June 5, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Grab an extra harness and leash. Know how to keep dogs safe during the pandemic
item.dc:creator: Anh Do
item.description: Grab an extra harness and leash. Here's what else experts say you can do to keep canines safe in the age of the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Grab an extra harness and leash. Here's what else experts say you can do to keep canines safe in the age of the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: CULVER CITY, CA-MAY 14, 2020: Lindsay Rojas, 28, owner of Lindsay's Dog Walks in Culver City, walks Gomez, left, and Nikki, brother and sister Golden Retrievers, on Keystone Ave. in Culver City. The dogs belong to an elderly woman named Riya who has multiple sclerosis. During the coronavirus pandemic, experts warn that dogs should not interact with other dogs outside their immediate family. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. is less cautious than Bay Area in coronavirus reopening. Here's why the two regions diverged
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Despite more coronavirus cases and deaths per capita, Los Angeles has moved faster to loosen social distancing requirements than the Bay Area.
item.content:encoded: Despite more coronavirus cases and deaths per capita, Los Angeles has moved faster to loosen social distancing requirements than the Bay Area.

media:content.media:description: SAN PEDRO, CA - MAY 29: A worker from La Siciliana brings out food for people sitting at a table along a section of Sixth Street that is closed down between Mesa and and Centre streets in San Pedro where seating for dining is on Friday, May 29, 2020 in San Pedro, CA. On Friday, Los Angeles County received permission to reopen restaurants for in-person dining and resume services at barbershops and hair salons, marking a new phase in the regions efforts to restart the devastated retail economy. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD Chief Moore under fire over looting remarks, police treatment of protesters
item.dc:creator: Cindy Chang
item.description: Los Angeles Police Chief Michel Moore is under fire for remarks he made about looters and the use of foam bullets and arrests of peaceful protesters after more than a week of civil unrest since the killing of George Floyd.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles Police Chief Michel Moore is under fire for remarks he made about looters and the use of foam bullets and arrests of peaceful protesters after more than a week of civil unrest since the killing of George Floyd.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA JUNE 5, 2020-LAPD Chief Michael Moore talks with protestors outside police headquarters after a candle light vigil for George Floyd Friday. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Students posted racist remarks online. These Granada Hills high schoolers are taking action

item.content:encoded: Anti-black online hate speech prompted students at Granada Hills Charter High School to speak out against racism.

media:content.media:description: NEWPORT BEACH, CA - JUNE 03: Black Lives Matter supporters rally at the Newport Beach Civic Center Park bridge to protest against racism and Minneapolis police officers' involvement in the May 25 death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man Wednesday, June 3, 2020 in Newport Beach, CA. It was the third of four protests in Newport Beach Wednesday. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Long Beach police officer standing over blood with his baton has been 'relieved' from department
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: The news comes a day after the department became aware of "a social media post an officer had on his Facebook page" that included "a baton and blood on the ground," according to an email sent Thursday by City Manager Tom Modica.
item.content:encoded: The news comes a day after the department became aware of "a social media post an officer had on his Facebook page" that included "a baton and blood on the ground," according to an email sent Thursday by City Manager Tom Modica.

item.title: LA Pride organizers under fire after seeking police permit for Black Lives Matter solidarity protest
item.dc:creator: Andrea Castillo
item.description: On Friday, the event producer released a statement of apology and withdrew his involvement.
item.content:encoded: On Friday, the event producer released a statement of apology and withdrew his involvement.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CA - JUNE 1, 2020: Thousands of demonstrators rallied in front of the Riverside Public Library to protest the death of George Floyd during the coronavirus pandemic on June 1, 2020 in Riverside, California. Police allowed them to stay 90 minutes after the 6pm curfew. Those that remained were dispersed as law enforcement fired tear gas and pellets.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: UCLA handling of sexual misconduct allegations against physicians 'inadequate,' report finds
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: An independent committee tasked with reviewing how UCLA handled allegations of sexual harassment and sexual misconduct by university-employed physicians described its response as 'delayed, inadequate or both.'
item.content:encoded: An independent committee tasked with reviewing how UCLA handled allegations of sexual harassment and sexual misconduct by university-employed physicians described its response as 'delayed, inadequate or both.'

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 26, 2019 - Dr. James Heaps, right, a former UCLA obstetrician-gynecologist appears in the Airport Branch Courthouse for a hearing June 26, 2019 with his attorney's Andrew Reed Flier and Tracy Green, accused of sexually battering patients. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Small plane carrying 3 people crashes on hillside near Redlands
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: The single-engine Cessna 172 crashed under unknown circumstances off Highway 38 and Mill Creek Road, authorities said.
item.content:encoded: The single-engine Cessna 172 crashed under unknown circumstances off Highway 38 and Mill Creek Road, authorities said.

media:content.media:description: A single-engine Cessna 172 crashed on a hillside near Hwy 38/Mill Creek Road in Redlands area under unknown circumstances on Friday afternoon, authorities said.

item.title: Advocates sue LAPD over protest tactics, alleging disabled homeless man was shot in face with rubber bullets
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: The suit accuses the LAPD of leaving curfew violators handcuffed on buses for up to 12 hours and of using force against a disabled homeless man in downtown Los Angeles
item.content:encoded: The suit accuses the LAPD of leaving curfew violators handcuffed on buses for up to 12 hours and of using force against a disabled homeless man in downtown Los Angeles

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA JUNE 2, 2020: LAPD arrive to arrests protestors for curfew vilotation after a day of peaceful protest against police brutality and to demonstrate in Los Angeles, CA. The protests were sparked by the death of George Floyd. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD chief expresses concern over videos of police violence during protests as calls mount for investigation
item.dc:creator: James Queally, Cindy Chang
item.description: Chief Michel Moore faces calls for an investigation into the LAPD's handling of protests after videos surfaced showing officers using batons and other force on unarmed protesters.
item.content:encoded: Chief Michel Moore faces calls for an investigation into the LAPD's handling of protests after videos surfaced showing officers using batons and other force on unarmed protesters.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- MONDAY, JANUARY 28, 2019: LAPD Chief Michel Moore announces that for the first time in five years, violent crime was down in Los Angeles in 2018, with the number of homicides on track to be among the lowest in more than 50 years during a press conference at LAPD headquarters in Los Angeles, Calif., on Jan. 28, 2019. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Fearing protests could spread virus, San Francisco has set up a pop-up testing site
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: San Francisco has set up a free COVID-19 testing clinic for people in the George Floyd protests to ensure they haven't been exposed to the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: San Francisco has set up a free COVID-19 testing clinic for people in the George Floyd protests to ensure they haven't been exposed to the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: MONTCLAIR, CA - APRIL 14: A public health care worker collects a nasal swab from Victor Guardavo for novel coronavirus testing at a drive-through sample collection event held by San Bernardino County Department of Public Health at Montclair Plaza, Montclair, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Santa Monica mayor and police chief face anger from protesters: 'You called in the National Guard!'
item.dc:creator: Arit John
item.description: Santa Monica mayor, police chief face tough questions from George Floyd protesters: "You called in the National Guard!"
item.content:encoded: Santa Monica mayor, police chief face tough questions from George Floyd protesters: "You called in the National Guard!"

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - JUNE 01: The National Guard stationed at the Santa Monica Pier on Ocean Ave at Colorado as brigades of people with brooms descended on the upscale shopping district of Santa Monica Monday morning after looters spent hours yesterday smashing windows, stealing items and setting several fires. Protestors once again gathered en masse in the midst of the coronavirus outbreak to protest the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died last week in police custody after a white Minneapolis police officer pinned him down by his neck for several minutes. Santa Monica on Monday, June 1, 2020 in Santa Monica, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Al Seib/Al Seib/Al Seib/Los Angeles Times

item.title: There's a black jobs crisis. Coronavirus is making it worse

item.content:encoded: Beneath the fury over George Floyd's death lie longstanding economic inequities that have plagued California's 2.6 million black people.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 04: Trusion Daniels, shown at his Los Angeles apartment, previously worked as a chef at LAX but has been laid off due to the coronavirus pandemic. Photo taken Thursday, June 4, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD union decries Garcetti's 'killers' comment. He says he wasn't talking about police

item.content:encoded: The union for L.A. police officers criticized Mayor Eric Garcetti on Friday for comments he made about cutting the LAPD budget.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 02: LA Mayor Eric Garcetti walks out to address protesters and clergy members from the Los Angeles area that are participating in a march and peaceful protest in downtown Los Angeles outside of LA City Hall and LAPD Headquarters on Tuesday, June 2, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Protests erupted across the country, with people outraged over the death of George Floyd, a black man killed after a white Minneapolis police officer pinned him to the ground with his knee. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column One: In the COVID-19 unit, saying goodbye to a mentor long distance
item.dc:creator: Francine Orr
item.description: A photographer documenting the coronavirus fight at Martin Luther King Jr. Community Hospital recalls her mentor, a nun who like hospital staff embodied care and compassion.
item.content:encoded: A photographer documenting the coronavirus fight at Martin Luther King Jr. Community Hospital recalls her mentor, a nun who like hospital staff embodied care and compassion.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 27: (Editor's note: Image for story by Francine Orr and not for generic use at this time. Mary Cooney/ photo editor) Patient Care Technician Rakeem Addison, (CQ), age 30, puts on his white gloves and his isolation gown before entering into a covid-19 patient's room at Martin Luther King, Jr., Community Hospital on Thursday, April 27, 2020 in the Willowbrook neighborhood located in South Los Angeles, CA. He is currently working on the COVID-19 Unit at MLKCH. He said he was homeless from about age 15 to age 25 years old. He said he got fed up being homeless and started surrounding himself with successful and wanted to a part of the healthcare system. He started as a volunteer. He said as a homeless person he would stay at friend's homes and then inside his car until it was towed. He also said he used to stay on the path near King Drew High School. He went to high school in Long Beach where he played basketball. He says his father was from West Africa, in Accra, Ghana. He says his family now says he is strong. He says this November it will be his forth year working here. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Newsom's listening tour stops in Stockton amid protests and calls for action
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom visited with black community leaders in Stockton, faith leaders in Sacramento and small business owners in Los Angeles on a listening tour amid the George Floyd protests in California.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom visited with black community leaders in Stockton, faith leaders in Sacramento and small business owners in Los Angeles on a listening tour amid the George Floyd protests in California.

item.title: Local mountain lion gives birth to three cute kittens
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: The three kittens -- P-82, P-83 and P-84 -- possibly bring much needed genetic diversity to the mountain lion population in the Santa Monica Mountains.
item.content:encoded: The three kittens -- P-82, P-83 and P-84 -- possibly bring much needed genetic diversity to the mountain lion population in the Santa Monica Mountains.

media:content.media:description: P-54, a three-year old mountain lion living in the Santa Monica Mountains, recently gave birth to a litter of kittens - males P-82 and P-83, and female P-84. Researchers believe this is her first litter.

item.title: Despite complications and curfews, San Francisco's Grace Cathedral uses art to commemorate George Floyd

item.content:encoded: The officer, who was not identified in an email sent Thursday by the city manager, has been removed from patrol duties pending an internal investigation, according to the letter.

item.title: California lawmakers promise to set rules for police use of rubber bullets amid George Floyd protests

item.title: Confusing alerts and nowhere to go: Homeless Angelenos exempt from curfew struggle even more
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: Homeless people have been exempted from the curfew in L.A. County, but being on the streets during the unrest has been extra challenging.
item.content:encoded: Homeless people have been exempted from the curfew in L.A. County, but being on the streets during the unrest has been extra challenging.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA-JUNE 3, 2020: Alex Jones, 31, and his girlfriend Maya Johnson, 18, are photographed outside their tent at a homeless encampment on 1st St. near Spring St. in downtown Los Angeles. They were both arrested and given tickets by the LAPD outside City Hall on Saturday night, where a protest was held over the death of George Floyd. Jones is holding the ticket that Johnson received. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'I haven't seen anything like it': Protests spread to unexpected places like Irvine

item.content:encoded: From North Hollywood to Irvine, demonstrations over the death of George Floyd have moved into atypical areas.

item.title: Amid Bay Area looting, Hayward gun store is robbed of 29 firearms
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan

item.content:encoded: A $10,000 reward is offered for information leading to an arrest in the theft of 29 firearms from the Bay Area store Richardson Tactical.

item.title: In Oakland, protesters turn streets into giant dance party: 'One more song'

item.content:encoded: Though the group was clearly breaking the city's 8 p.m. curfew, the Oakland Police Department didn't disrupt the rollicking demonstration.

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators raise their fists during a "Sit Out the Curfew" protest against the death of George Floyd who died on May 25 in Minneapolis whilst in police custody, along a street in Oakland, California on June 3, 2020. - US protesters welcomed new charges against Minneapolis officers in the killing of African-American man George Floyd -- but thousands still marched in cities across the country for a ninth straight night, chanting against racism and police brutality. (Photo by Philip Pacheco / AFP) (Photo by PHILIP PACHECO/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: California coronavirus cases surpass 120,000; protests, closed testing sites worry health officials

Protests erupted across the country, with people outraged over the death of George Floyd, a black man killed after a white Minneapolis police officer pinned him to the ground with his knee. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Man brandishes handgun at protester in Newport Beach

item.content:encoded: Video shows a shirtless white man pulling a handgun out of a backpack and pointing it in the air as a black man hides behind a car.

It was the second of four protests Wednesday in Newport Beach. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: She's an essential worker, helping the homeless. But ICE plans to deport her next week

item.content:encoded: Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials plan to deport a 48-year-old mother of four who is an essential worker during the coronavirus pandemic.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA -- MAY 28: Mariana (not her real name), a single mother of four children, at her home on Thursday, May 28, 2020, in Ventura, CA. Mariana cleans a hotel, Vagabond Inn, that is currently being used by California and Ventura County to house people who are at-risk for catching the coronavirus - including the homeless population in the county - is facing deportation on June 11. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Using tear gas to subdue protesters may further spread the coronavirus, experts warn

Thousands of protesters marched through the street of downtown Riverside and police alloyed them to stay 90 minutes after the 6pm curfew.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

The shooting occurred when a group that had entered a Walgreens rammed a police officer outside, City Manager Greg Nyhoff said in a statement, he did not say whether the suspect survived. (AP Photo/Ben Margot)

item.title: Fundraiser pleads guilty in L.A. City Hall corruption case
item.dc:creator: Joel Rubin

item.content:encoded: A political operative pleaded guilty to helping to bribe a city councilmember

media:content.media:description: It wasn't so much that voters rejected female candidates for the 11 offices on this year's ballot, although Wendy Greuel and Jan Perry were both serious candidates for mayor, and Ana Cubas made the runoff in the 9th Council District race but fell short. But there were no women at all running for city attorney or controller, or for several of the City Council offices. From July 1, when the all-male victors took office, to Aug. 2, when they were joined by new Councilwoman Nury Martinez, Los Angeles City Hall had no elected women in office for the first time in decades. Above: L.A. City Hall. MORE YEAR IN REVIEW: Ted Rall's five best cartoons of 2013 6 developments that changed Latin America in 201310 tips for a better life from The Times' Op-Ed pages in 2013

item.title: Newsom says California would 'reject' Trump's attempts to send military into major cities
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna, Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom said California would reject any attempt by President Trump to send the military into states to control protests following the death of George Floyd.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom said California would reject any attempt by President Trump to send the military into states to control protests following the death of George Floyd.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 03, 2020 - - California Governor Gavin Newsom, right, listens as he is introduced to Kirikou Muldrow, 8, by California Senator Holly Mitchell and California Assembly Member Sydney Kamlager-Dove, right, during a visit to the Hot and Cool Cafe in Leimert Park after several days of protest in Los Angeles on June 3, 2020. The cafe has been providing meals for senior citizens 3 days a week during the coronavirus pandemic stay at home order. Muldrow has been helping pack the meals. Her mother is co-owner of the the cafe. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Among California reopenings: Pickleball courts. So, what's pickleball?

Archer and Payne met last year at the El Segundo courts, when a group of pickleball players would gather to play. They are also a part of a pickle ball text group that is used to plan meetups. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Pediatricians say kids should be in school despite coronavirus risk

Vivian Ekchian, right, are given a tour of Cerritos Elementary in Glendale by Principal Perla Chavez-Fritz, center, on Tuesday May 26, 2020 considering that with a persisting coronavirus threat, K-12 campuses will try to reopen in the fall. New L.A. County guidelines offer a possible roadmap but it could get complicated and costly to confront the logistics of reopening at an actual school in the wake of Covid-19. Glendale on Tuesday, May 26, 2020 in Glendale, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Heartbreaking': These families were set to adopt, but coronavirus put their plans on hold
item.dc:creator: Seema Mehta
item.description: Coronavirus-prompted court closures are making thousands of California families wait to adopt as their hearings are pushed farther and farther back.
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus-prompted court closures are making thousands of California families wait to adopt as their hearings are pushed farther and farther back.

media:content.media:description: Stephanie Rivero and Ryan Cameron carry their foster sons, ages 5 and 8. The Merced couple's adoption of the boys has been pushed back because of the court closures during the pandemic. That may delay the younger boy's planned surgery for a live-threatening condition.

item.title: Santa Ana man threw fireworks at police during protest, authorities say
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: After arresting the man at his home, police said they found more than 600 pounds of illegal fireworks and a cache of weapons and ammunition.
item.content:encoded: After arresting the man at his home, police said they found more than 600 pounds of illegal fireworks and a cache of weapons and ammunition.

media:content.media:description: Santa Ana police arrested Jon Paul Worden after officers said he threw mortars at law enforcement officials during a protest May 31. Police found a cache of weapons and ammunition in his home.

item.title: Newsom orders new California in-person voting rules for November election
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom will allow California counties to provide fewer in-person voting locations if they also offer three days of early voting.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom will allow California counties to provide fewer in-person voting locations if they also offer three days of early voting.

media:content.media:description: Dorr Looman votes at Malibu Hindu Temple polling station in the state primary election on June 7, 2016 in Calabasas, California.

item.title: LAPD Chief Michel Moore's comments on looters create political firestorm
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, Cindy Chang, Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: Los Angeles Police Chief Michel Moore apologized minutes after condemning looters and saying George Floyd's 'death is on their hands.'
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles Police Chief Michel Moore apologized minutes after condemning looters and saying George Floyd's 'death is on their hands.'

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -- MAY 30: Michel Moore, second from left, Chief of Police for the Los Angeles Police Department, lets protestors who are demonstrating that the area is closed at W 3rd St and S Fairfax Ave. in the Fairfax District on Saturday, May 30, 2020, in Los Angeles, CA. The protestors demonstrate in response to the death of George Floyd in Minnesota. Last night more than 500 arrests after looting and vandalism sweep downtown L.A. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's legal pot industry faces year of decline because of coronavirus, Newsom warns
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California's legal marijuana industry faces a year of decline as a result of the coronavirus, despite dispensaries being deemed essential businesses.
item.content:encoded: California's legal marijuana industry faces a year of decline as a result of the coronavirus, despite dispensaries being deemed essential businesses.

media:content.media:description: Sean McDermott (left), owner of The Grove cannabis shop in La Mesa, looks over one of the store's products with Larry Fennell, one of his first hires from the summer of 2018. The site on Center Street was the first in East County authorized by California to sell adult-use cannabis products. McDermott said he received confirmation from the state by mail on May 6 and The Grove had its first recreational cannabis product sale on May 7.

item.title: Protests planned for Newport Beach after tense standoff at South Coast Plaza
item.dc:creator: Gustavo Arellano, Ben Brazil, Hillary Davis
item.description: Four demonstrations, at least one of them billed as family friendly, are scheduled across Newport Beach on Wednesday.
item.content:encoded: Four demonstrations, at least one of them billed as family friendly, are scheduled across Newport Beach on Wednesday.

media:content.media:description: There was a series of standoffs between protesters and police at a rally at South Coast Plaza late Monday night.

item.title: As 'defund LAPD' becomes a rallying cry, Garcetti will seek cuts up to $150 million
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes, David Zahniser, Dakota Smith
item.description: Mayor Eric Garcetti says the LAPD will see budget cuts of $100 million to $150 million.
item.content:encoded: Mayor Eric Garcetti says the LAPD will see budget cuts of $100 million to $150 million.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 02: Law enforcement personnel stand in front of LAPD HQ as demonstrators chant in downtown Los Angeles on Tuesday, June 2, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Protests have erupted across the country, with people outraged over the death of George Floyd, a black man killed after a white Minneapolis police officer pinned him to the ground with his knee. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'A good army': L.A. protesters from diverse backgrounds converge on streets
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia, Julia Wick, Matt Hamilton, Jaclyn Cosgrove, Dorany Pineda, Alejandra Reyes-Velarde, Liam Dillon
item.description: Thousands peacefully took to the street in Hollywood and DTLA in what appeared to be the city's biggest protests since George Floyd's death last week.
item.content:encoded: Thousands peacefully took to the street in Hollywood and DTLA in what appeared to be the city's biggest protests since George Floyd's death last week.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 02: Recording artist Chela Alvarado, center, raises her arm joining protestors in front of National Guardsmen as they stand guard closing Sunset Blvd at Vine Street in Hollywood as protesters made of mostly students marched through Hollywood Tuesday afternoon to protest the death of George Floyd during an arrest in Minneapolis last week. The group gathered at the intersection of Hollywood Blvd and Vine Street for a peaceful demonstration and marched through parts of Hollywood encountering LAPD officers and National Guardsmen. Hollywood on Tuesday, June 2, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 2 wounded, 3 arrested after South L.A. shooting triggers police pursuit
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Officers responded to Broadway and Manchester Avenue shortly after midnight after hearing gunshots.
item.content:encoded: Officers responded to Broadway and Manchester Avenue shortly after midnight after hearing gunshots.

media:content.media:description: Authorities surround a vehicle after a shooting in South Los Angeles triggered a police pursuit early Wednesday. (OnScene.TV)

item.title: UC dropped the SAT. Should you take it anyway?
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: The University of California made headlines by dropping SAT and ACT requirements. But students should still take them, many high school counselors say.
item.content:encoded: The University of California made headlines by dropping SAT and ACT requirements. But students should still take them, many high school counselors say.

media:content.media:description: PEMBROKE PINES, FL - MARCH 06: A college applicant uses an SAT Preparation book to study for the test on March 6, 2014 in Pembroke Pines, Florida.

item.title: L.A. Pride announces Black Lives Matter solidarity protest march for June 14
item.dc:creator: Jessica Roy
item.description: This year's L.A. Pride will be a peaceful protest march in solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement, organizers announced. It will take place June 14 starting at Hollywood and Highland.
item.content:encoded: This year's L.A. Pride will be a peaceful protest march in solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement, organizers announced. It will take place June 14 starting at Hollywood and Highland.

media:content.media:description: HERMOSA BEACH, CA - JUNE 02: Several hundred Black Lives Matter protesters take a knee and hold their fists in the air during a moment of silence to honor George Floyd during a peaceful protest march from Manhattan Beach to Hermosa Beach and return at the Hermosa Beach Pier Plaza Tuesday, June 2, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: South L.A. is largely untouched by unrest. That is by design
item.dc:creator: Angel Jennings
item.description: Black Lives Matter organizers wanted to bring the rage over the George Floyd case and so many others to L.A.'s elites, in their own neighborhoods.
item.content:encoded: Black Lives Matter organizers wanted to bring the rage over the George Floyd case and so many others to L.A.'s elites, in their own neighborhoods.

media:content.media:description: LAPD officer Delwin Fields guards the intersection at Central and 46th Street on April 30, 1992.

item.title: Hype and science collide as FDA tries to rein in 'wild West' of COVID-19 blood tests
item.dc:creator: JoNel Aleccia, Anna Maria Barry-Jester
item.description: The FDA is trying to rein in the chaos it created by allowing companies to flood the market with COVID-19 antibody tests of questionable accuracy.
item.content:encoded: The FDA is trying to rein in the chaos it created by allowing companies to flood the market with COVID-19 antibody tests of questionable accuracy.

media:content.media:description: In Mira Mesa, an employee takes a blood test to determine if he carries coronavirus antibodies.
media:content.media:credit: Nelvin C. Cepeda/The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: LAPD tactics get more aggressive as arrests soar
item.dc:creator: James Queally, Kevin Rector, Alejandra Reyes-Velarde, Richard Winton
item.description: With Los Angeles under nightly curfews and looting breaking out in neighborhoods across the city and county, arrests have surged into the thousands.
item.content:encoded: With Los Angeles under nightly curfews and looting breaking out in neighborhoods across the city and county, arrests have surged into the thousands.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, Tuesday, June 2, 2020 - LAPD officer Decote watches for people tossing debris from tall buildings as dozens of protesters are arrested for curfew violations on Broadway. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Inland Empire protests fueled by cases of past police violence
item.dc:creator: Paloma Esquivel
item.description: Protests over the death of George Floyd also taking place in the Inland Empire, which has its own history of police abuses and violence.
item.content:encoded: Protests over the death of George Floyd also taking place in the Inland Empire, which has its own history of police abuses and violence.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CA - JUNE 1, 2020: Thousands of demonstrators rallied in front of the Riverside Public Library to protest the death of George Floyd during the coronavirus pandemic on June 1, 2020 in Riverside, California. Police allowed them to stay 90 minutes after the 6pm curfew. Those that remained were dispersed as law enforcement fired tear gas and pellets.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)
